ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It is a fantastic, informative and important course taught by a funny, informed, passionate BAD ASS professor.
This is a survey of Islamic political thought with regard to the state and to a lesser extent democracy. I would recommend it to anybody interested in Islamic societies.

This course looks at Islamic political theorists from the 19th century into the 21st century, and the guiding question that forms the core of the course is about the relationship (and its history) between Islam and democracy. Pretty much anyone who studies a whole range of things - political theory, law, global affairs, political science, religious studies, Islamic studies - could significantly benefit from this course. Also, because Professor March is amazing, I would take anything he offers in the future, even if it's not this class.
Only if they were interested in Islam and politics.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Informed a lot of my interests moving forward. Very very valuable.
This course r helped me better understand the politics in my country, Saudi Arabia, and how almost everything that happens in the country is tied to that.
